name: ARM Outputs
description: This task reads the output values of an ARM deployment and sets them as Azure Pipelines variables.
author: Kees Schollaart
releaseNotes: Complete rewrite from PowerShell to Node to enable Linux based agents

inputs.name: ConnectedServiceNameARM
inputs.label: AzureRM Subscription
inputs.helpMarkDown: Select the Azure Resource Manager subscription.

inputs.name: resourceGroupName
inputs.label: Resource Group
inputs.helpMarkDown: Provide the name of the resource group.

inputs.name: prefix
inputs.label: Prefix
inputs.helpMarkDown: Provide a prefix for all Pipelines variable to set (the prefix is added to the key/name of the ARM output(s)).

inputs.name: outputNames
inputs.label: Outputs to process
inputs.helpMarkDown: Provide a comma-separated list of ARM outputs (key/name) to process. If left empty, all outputs are processed.

inputs.name: whenLastDeploymentIsFailed
inputs.label: When last deployment is failed
inputs.helpMarkDown: Choose the behavior when the latest deployment is not successful.

inputs.name: deploymentNameFilter
inputs.label: Filter deployment name
inputs.helpMarkDown:
Optional string to filter deployments by. This can be useful if you have concurrent deployments to the same resource group. Deployment names in Azure Pipelines are the name of the JSON file plus the date and time, so a file `CreateKeyVault.json` could have a deployment name of `CreateKeyVault-20180025-151538-0688`. In this case, if you want to filter to deployments of this file enter `CreateKeyVault` as the filter.

This uses [micromatch](https://github.com/micromatch/micromatch) under the hood (ignoring case) so us wildcards like *

inputs.name: setAsOutput
inputs.label: Set as Output variables.
inputs.helpMarkDown: In case the variables needs to be shared in other jobs or stages, they need to be set as Output variables. Select this option to output all of the retrieved variables as Output variables.
